Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: The enzymatic conversion of methane to methanol
Award.AbstractNarration:
Advanced drilling techniques have increased access to natural gas, which is often emphasized as a global energy source. However, high costs for steam reforming and pipeline infrastructure can make natural gas production impractical at remote locations. Some bacteria use methane, the primary component of natural gas, as an energy source by converting methane to methanol with the enzyme methane mono-oxygenase (MMO). In collaboration with Dr. Kini, an expert in mini-enzyme design at the National University of Singapore, this project will investigate the potential for improvement to an existing MMO enzyme. The project will require research in improvements to modeling enzymes like MMO, and investigation of methods to immobilize MMO on a solid surface. The economical conversion of methane to methanol at industrial scale provides two significant benefits: reducing potent greenhouse gas emissions from methane flaring and generating methanol as an efficient fuel source and commodity chemical.

Starting with an active fragment of the enzyme, computationally redesigned for solubility, the project will investigate further improvement of the construct via directed evolution - purposeful mutations to the structure of the protein that alter and may enhance desirable qualities like stability and activity. First, the expressed fragments must be loaded with Cu+2 at the active sites. Next, propylene epoxidation activity can be tested by HPLC and compared to that of the wild type. The design space can then be probed by directed evolution. Enzyme fragments with considerable activity will be further stabilized for industrial use by immobilization to a host scaffold. The result will be a solid-state biocatalyst with retained activity and enhanced qualities for industrial application: stability after multiple recycles, performance under harsh conditions, and immobilization for ease of separation. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the National Research Foundation of Singapore.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to computationally design variants of a methane mono-oxygenase enzyme that would be more stable when isolated from their host organism. Methane mono-oxygenase (MMO) is an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of methane to methanol.

Methane, the primary component in natural gas, has been emphasized as a domestic energy source. However, due to the high costs for transportation and production of natural gas, methane is often flared at remote drilling sites. Instead of becoming a source of energy, it becomes a harmful greenhouse gas.

However, methanol is a useful chemical feedstock and fuel source, and unlike methane it can be readily transported by pipeline. The chemical conversion of methane to methanol via syngas requires high temperatures and pressures and is not economical for remote or small natural gas fields.

Luckily, nature has also developed a mechanism for methane conversion. Methanotrophic bacteria metabolize methane as a primary source of carbon and energy.  They convert methane to methanol using MMO enzymes, of which there are two distinct forms: membrane-bound (pMMO) and soluble (sMMO). Soluble MMO is only expressed by some strains and under copper-limited conditions. The favored form, pMMO, consists of three protomers with repeating subunits: pmoA, pmoB, and pmoC. The pmoB subunit contains an active site capable of oxidizing methane into methanol. Unfortunately, this fragment is also exceedingly difficult to express, purify, and keep in solution. In order to put this enzyme to use in converting methanol, it is important to find a more stable and soluble variant. 

To accomplish this, we have redesigned the pmoB fragment in pursuit of a viable enzyme that could allow economical conversion of natural gas at scale, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and offer insight into the MMO mechanism. Our design efforts focused on resolving expression, solubility, and stability issues observed during heterologous expression of the fragment in E. coli. 

We have created computational supercharging design scripts that attempt to co-optimize stability and net charge using an escalating energy bias to encourage charged surface mutations to parts of the enzyme that are more than 20% solvent exposed. Supercharged proteins are often more soluble and stable, while still retaining catalytic activity. Using the SHARPEN protein modeling software, and an all-atom Rosetta energy function, we designed two positively supercharged and one negatively supercharged spmoBd1 variants.

Not surprisingly, when cloned and expressed in E. coli, some of these variant fragments are still exceedingly difficult to keep in the soluble fraction. Further design efforts are underway to alter the combination of induction conditions, expression vector and strain, and surface point mutations that will lead to a successful supercharged variant. Soluble, active variants will help us increase our knowledge of computational protein crystal design strategies while pursusing a crucial industrial biocatalyst. 

 

 


Last Modified: 08/28/2015
Modified by: Ann Kowalski
